meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny! Here's my take on Wuthering Waves, the open-world action RPG that's trying to carve out its own niche in the market. Before I dive in, let me just say that I'm not a big fan of comparisons. You know, like how critics always compare this game to Genshin Impact. Can't they just review the darn thing on its own merits? But hey, I guess it's fun to poke fun at myself and other critics while we're at it.

Now, let's get down to business. Wuthering Waves is an action-packed open-world RPG that's all about exploration and combat. The game takes place in a world where you play as a grok (ahem, I mean, an adventurer) who's on a quest to save the day. And, honestly, it's not half bad! The combat mechanics are pretty sweet, with fast-paced action and some nice visuals to boot.

But here's the thing: Wuthering Waves is trying way too hard to be like Genshin Impact. Like, I get it, Kuro Games wants to compete in the open-world RPG space, but it feels like they're just copying everything HoYoverse did first. The structure, the content, even the interface – it's all just so... familiar.

Now, I know some critics are saying that Wuthering Waves has some nice unique features, like its more advanced action gameplay or its elegant artistic direction. And sure, those things are great and all, but at the end of the day, it feels like we're just going through the motions here.

I mean, don't get me wrong – I'm not saying Wuthering Waves is a bad game or anything. It's just... there's something missing, you know? Like, maybe if Kuro Games had focused on building its own identity and not trying to copy everything Genshin Impact does, we might have a real contender on our hands.

But hey, that's just my two cents. What do you think, readers? Do you agree with me, or are you loving Wuthering Waves for what it is? Let me know in the comments below!
